mnemonic: UM sounds like 'oom' - imagine going 'oom' when you see ONE thing
grammar_notes: Masculine singular indefinite article. Also means 'one'.
cultural_note: In Portugal 'um' is often used when ordering - 'Um café' (a/one coffee).
tip: Nasal 'u' - used for masculine singular nouns

mnemonic: UMA = UM + A for feminine. Think 'Um-ah one lady!'
grammar_notes: Feminine singular indefinite article. Also means 'one'.
cultural_note: 'Uma bica' (an espresso) is how locals order coffee in Lisbon!

grammar_notes: Masculine plural indefinite. The 's' sounds like 'sh' in European Portuguese.
cultural_note: Portuguese often drop 'uns/umas' in casual speech - just say 'livros novos'.

mnemonic: UMAS = UMA + S. Think 'Oomash some ladies!'
cultural_note: 'Umas cervejas' (some beers) is a common order at Portuguese tascas (taverns).

mnemonic: 'Oh MAN!' sounds like HOMEM - that's a man!
cultural_note: 'Um homem de palavra' means a man of his word - highly valued in Portuguese culture.
example2_en: I saw a man in the street.

mnemonic: MUL-HER: A MULE carrying HER bags - that woman works hard!
cultural_note: Portuguese women are often highly educated - highest rate of female managers in EU!

mnemonic: COPO sounds like 'cop-oh' - imagine a COP holding his glass
cultural_note: 'Um copo de vinho' is the traditional way to order wine in Portugal.
example2_en: I want a glass of wine.

mnemonic: CHÁVENA sounds like 'shave-ena' - shave in a cup-sized mirror
grammar_notes: European Portuguese word. Brazil uses 'xícara'. Use 'uma' (feminine).
cultural_note: Portugal is famous for its coffee culture - 'uma bica' in Lisbon 'um cimbalino' in Porto!

mnemonic: PRATO sounds like 'prat-oh' - the plate goes SPLAT-OH if dropped
grammar_notes: 'Prato' is masculine - use 'um'. Also means 'dish' (as in food dish).
cultural_note: 'Prato do dia' (dish of the day) is often the best value at Portuguese restaurants!

mnemonic: GARRAFA sounds like 'ga-RAFF-a' - a giraffe drinking from a bottle
grammar_notes: 'Garrafa' is feminine - use 'uma'. The 'rr' is rolled in Portuguese.
cultural_note: Portuguese wine bottles often have unique regional shapes - recognizable by locals!
